questions.text: A mother brought her 7-year-old child to the OPD because of fever and facial swelling for the past 2 days. She says that he has been refusing to eat because of the pain near the jaw. He has not been vaccinated since birth because of his parent's fear of side effects. On examination, a tender swelling is noted on the jaw as shown in the picture. Which of the following statement is true regarding this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: Salivary gland involvement is limited to the parotids
Patient is not infectious prior to clinical parotid enlargement

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mumps. Meningoencephalitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis.

Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain.

It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at  9 months, 15 months and 4-6 years.

Option B: Mumps can affect all the salivary glands, but most commonly affects parotid glands.

Option C: The patient is infectious from 7 days before to 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

Option D: Orchitis or oophoritis is a common finding in mumps, along with parotitis. But, mumps leading to infertility is very rare.

questions.text: An outbreak of mumps infection was reported from a local school a few days ago. A boy studying in the 2nd standard of that school presented with painful bilateral swelling near his jaw and cheek for 3 days. His mother is anxious about the possible complications of the disease. Which of the following is the most common complication that can occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Meningoencephalitis is the most common complication that can occur in mumps in children. 

Most common complications in mumps:

  • Children - Meningoencephalitis
  • Adolescents and adult males - Orchitis

questions.text: On your pediatrics rotation, you notice a 2-day-old baby with the rash shown in the image below. Which among the following is the most likely cause for this baby's rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows purple papulonodular lesions, which are suggestive of blueberry muffin rash. It is seen in congenital rubella.

Blueberry muffin rash represents dermal erythropoiesis. In addition to congenital rubella, it can be seen in: 

  • Congenital viral infections such as cytomegalovirus and parvovirus
  • Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and acute myeloid leukemia
  • Rh hemolytic disease

questions.text: A woman who came with complaints of fever, myalgia, and rash at 12 weeks of gestation is found to have positive IgM titers for rubella. She is advised MTP. If the pregnancy is taken to full term, which of the following triad of complications would you expect to see in the child?

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly
Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects
Sensorineural hearing loss, cataract, congenital heart defects

questions.solution:
The patient has an increased risk of congenital rubella if the pregnancy is taken full term. The triad of complications that would be expected in the child include:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss: Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease: The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus

Option A: Chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications - congenital toxoplasmosis.

Option B: Sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, microcephaly - congenital CMV infection.

Option C: Cataracts, cicatricial skin lesions, limb defects - congenital varicella syndrome.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. The child's parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is pneumonia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia).

Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate ≥of 90%. The patients are infectious from 4 days before upto 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots are pathognomonic.

The most common cause of death is pneumonia. Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication.

Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

questions.text: A young child presented with fever and cough in the OPD. He is observed to have the finding shown in the image below on the inner aspect of cheeks. Which of the following statement is false regarding this clinical finding?

choices.text: It appears 1 to 4 days before the rash
It appears as tiny-rose colored lesions
It is seen at the level of molars
It may also occur in conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The image shows discrete red lesions with white spots in the center on the inner aspect of the cheeks, suggestive of Koplik spots. They do not appear as tiny rose-colored lesions. 

Koplik spots are pathognomonic of measles. These are the spots present at the level of molars. They appear 1-4 days prior to the rash. They may also occur in conjunctival folds and vaginal mucosa. 

Forchheimer spots: Tiny red-colored lesions in the oropharynx or petechial hemorrhages on the soft palate, seen in rubella (German measles).

 

Koplik's spots: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st Edition says "at the level of premolars." However, most other resources, including Harrison's 20th edition, say "level of molars."

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of myoclonic jerks, seizures, and rapid decline in cognitive function. The mother gives a history of fever with a rash at 1.5 years of age. The rash had started behind the ears, progressed to involve the whole body, and resolved on its own. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a classic history of exanthematous fever suggestive of measles, seizures, myoclonic jerks, and cognitive dysfunction is suggestive of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).

SSPE is a chronic, progressive demyelinating disease that develops years after measles infection, most often in patients between 5-15 years of age. Patients have a history of measles infection at <2 years of age. CSF shows elevated measles antibody levels and MRI shows increased T2 intensity in white matter. No definitive treatment is available. 

Other complications of measles:

  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Giant-cell pneumonitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Croup
  • Secondary infections - otitis media
  • Protracted diarrhea

questions.text: Akshay developed a fever, headache, and a diffuse rash as shown below. The rash is most prominent on the face and chest. He says the rash is very itchy bothering his everyday life. He is a football player and has an upcoming tournament in the next few days. He wants to know if he'll be able to play by then. Considering the rash infectivity, until when would you advise him to stay isolated?

choices.text: 4 days after the appearance of lesions
7 days after the appearance of lesions
14 days after the appearance of lesions
After crust formation has occurred over lesions

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of chickenpox. You would advise the boy to stay isolated until after crust formation has occurred over lesions. 

People with chickenpox are contagious 24-48 hours before the rash is evident and until the vesicles have crusted, which is usually 3-7 days after the onset of rash.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

Until 48 hours of antibiotics.

3 weeks.

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of chickenpox among the children at a daycare center. What is the most common extracutaneous site of involvement of this disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extracutaneous site of involvement by the varicella-zoster virus in children is the central nervous system. It is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization.

The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus.

The most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

questions.text: Seema is brought to the OPD due to the development of a very itchy rash. Her father says he's worried because she has been constantly scratching her body leading to scratch marks. Before the development of the rash, she had a fever and headache for 2 days. On examination, you note a vesicular rash, which is in different stages of evolution. Which of the following is not a possible complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of Varicella-zoster infection. It occurs due to measles.

The characteristic rash of chickenpox is present in different stages of evolution.

Complications of VZV occur with disseminated varicella or with reactivation of infection. This more commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. Complications include:

  • Bacterial infections of the skin and soft tissues
  • Pneumonia
  • Hepatitis
  • Acute cerebellar ataxia
  • Encephalitis
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Sepsis
  • Shingles/Herpes Zoster: vesicular lesions are confined to the unilateral segment of the sensory nerve (dermatome). In children, the rash is mild, with complete resolution within 1-2 week. Unlike in adults, postherpetic neuralgia is unusual in children.

questions.text: A child presents with fever, headache, and a diffuse rash as shown below. The rash resolves by crusting and the child recovers in 10 days. Which spinal segments are most commonly involved in a latent reactivation of this infection?

choices.text: It involves all spinal segments equally

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of chickenpox. Latent reactivation of the infection or shingles most commonly occurs in the T3 to L3 spinal segments.  

Herpes zoster/shingles are characterized by a unilateral vesicular dermatomal eruption associated with severe pain.

 

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. It is shown below:

 

Ramsay–Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) affects the facial nerve with an eruption on the tympanic membrane, the external auditory canal, and facial palsy.

questions.text: You are a pediatrics resident posted in the labor room. You are examining a baby which was delivered via C-section a few minutes ago. You notice that the baby has zig-zag hypertrophic cutaneous scarring in a dermatomal distribution on the left side of the limbs and face. He also has a small head and small limbs. Antenatal history of the mother will be significant for which of the following infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, antenatal history of varicella infection would be significant in the mother of this baby.

Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy.

Clinical features include:

  • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cataracts
  • Optic atrophy
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Motor and sensory deficits.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, urine is the best sample to be sent for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. 

In congenital CMV infections, the investigation of choice is PCR or viral culture. It should be done within the first three weeks of life (after this period, it is difficult to distinguish between a congenital and an acquired infection). Since not all affected infants are viremic at birth, urine is a more reliable sample than blood. 

Most CMV transmission occurs in the first trimester. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. 90% of the infected babies are asymptomatic and have lesser chances of having late sequelae. 

The clinical manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with complaints of a rash and fever. The worried parents say the rash appeared on his cheeks yesterday. However, this morning, they observed it has spread to the trunk as well.  The image of the child is given below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is also known as sixth disease
It is caused by an RNA virus
It is associated with a transient arrest of erythropoiesis
It is associated with immune fetal hydrops

questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic slapped cheek appearance of a rash, which is classically present in parvovirus B-19 infection or erythema infectiosum. This is associated with transient aplastic crisis and erythropoiesis is mainly affected.

Erythema infectiosum is also known as the fifth disease. The rash appears first on the cheeks called the slapped cheek appearance then spreads to the trunk. It is caused by parvovirus B-19, which a single-stranded DNA virus.

Clinical features:

  • Febrile, non-toxic child with a nonspecific prodrome
  • Transient aplastic anemia, pure red cell aplasia
  • Petechial/ purpuric skin eruptions: Papular purpuric “gloves and socks” syndrome (PPGSS)
  • Myocarditis
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise
  • Arthritis and arthralgia (adults)

questions.text: Niki, a 9-month-old baby is brought to the OPD for a rash. The mother says the baby had a high fever of 103 F for 3 days for which she was given paracetamol. This morning, the baby had no fever but the mother noticed a rash on the trunk. On oral examination, ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction are present. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is also called as erythema subitum
It is caused by human herpes virus-6
It is a non-pruritic, morbilliform rash on the trunk

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of roseola infantum. It is also called exanthema subitum, not erythema subitum.

Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum (exanthema=breaking out, subitum=sudden rash). It is caused by a human herpesvirus (HHV) -6A, 6B, and 7.

Clinical features:

  • Prodrome of high-grade fever
  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

Image: Exanthem subitum

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came to the OPD with the complaint of fever and sore throat. On examination, you noted generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image of the peripheral blood film shows atypical lymphocytes, also known as Downey cells. The given clinical scenario along with characteristic atypical lymphocytes is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.

Infectious mononucleosis, also called, glandular fever is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). It is transmitted person-to-person through salivary secretions and blood transfusion. The incubation period is 4 to 5 weeks. It presents with a classic triad of

  • Fever
  • Pharyngitis
  • Lymphadenopathy

Other clinical features include fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. The patients are advised to avoid contact sports for 3-4 weeks due to the risk of splenic rupture. 

The screening test of choice is the monospot test. This is a heterophile antibody test. Atypical lymphocytosis of >10% is a characteristic laboratory finding. These are CD8 T lymphocytes that develop in response to the infected B lymphocytes.

Other diseases caused by EBV include:

  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Burkitt's lymphoma
  • Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma 

Option B: Kimura disease is s a chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Scrofuloderma is the result of cutaneous infection adjacent to a tuberculous focus, which may correspond to peripheral ganglionar tuberculosis (the most common form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis in HIV-positive patients and in children).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infantile  diarrhea worldwide?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of infantile diarrhea worldwide is rotavirus.

Rotavirus causes diarrhea in children of 3-5 years of age, via the fecal-oral route. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. This is presumably because of the protection by maternal antibodies in breast milk. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens

Lactose intolerance is actually not very common in infants and typically only starts showing up after age 3. All babies are born with lactase in their intestines. As they grow older, the lactase enzyme decreases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of hepatitis B from the infected mother to the baby?
questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not a mode of transmission of hepatitis B from an infected mother to the baby.

Mother-to-child transmission of HBV can occur via the following three routes:

  • Intrauterine transmission
  • Transmission during delivery (most frequent method)
  • Postpartum transmission

Postpartum transmission: A proportion of babies may acquire the infection after birth due to close contact with the mother. However, breastfeeding is not a risk factor for HBV infection.

Transmission following amniocentesis has been described, but the risk appears low.

Newborns born to seropositive Hepatitis B mothers are given Hep B immunoglobulin as well as Hep B vaccination at birth.

questions.text: Which fungal infection spreads in neonates through the care giver's hand?
questions.solution: Candida parapsilosis is increasingly responsible for hospital outbreaks, and the hands of healthcare workers may be predominant environment sources.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with rigidity and difficulty in movement. He has a history of involuntary movements in a single group of muscles of legs suggestive of myoclonic jerks. On examination, choreoathetosis movements and lead pipe rigidity is noted in the limbs. EEG shows suppression-burst episodes which are characteristic for subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. This clinical presentation is a complication of which of the following infection?
questions.solution:
Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles. Hence, prior infection with measles is most likely.

SSPE occurs 3-8 years after a primary measles infection. It is the least common complication of measles but is almost always fatal.

The clinical manifestations occur in 4 stages:

Stage I: Maybe missed due to mild symptoms like irritability and reduced attention span.

Stage II: Hallmark is massive Myoclonus. Involuntary muscle movements and myoclonic jerks start from one group of muscles but gives way to massive spams and jerks.

Stage III: Involuntary movements disappear and are replaced by choreoathetosis, immobility, dystonia, and lead-pipe rigidity due to destruction of deeper parts of basal ganglia.

Stage IV: Loss of critical centers that lead to coma and then death.

Diagnosis of SSPE is by:

  • Detection of measles antibody in CSF
  • Characteristic findings on EEG
  • Typical histological findings or/and isolation of virus or virus antigen from brain tissue obtained by biopsy or after postmortem.

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

Cardiac anomalies have been observed in 50% of children infected during the first 8 weeks of gestation. The incidence of heart disease in congenital rubella syndrome is: PDA > PS (right >left) > ventricular septal defect > atrial septal defect.

  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows small red lesions with bluish-white spots in the center on the inner aspects of the cheek opposite to the lower premolar, indicating the presence of Koplik spots. The appearance of these spots, along with a rash appearing three days later, strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. 

The measles virus is a single-stranded RNA virus. Measles infection has 4 phases: the incubation period, prodromal illness, exanthematous phase (characterized by the rash), and recovery phase. 

After an incubation period of 8-12 days, the prodromal phase of measles starts with mild fever and is followed by conjunctivitis, photophobia, coryza, cough, and increasing fever. Koplik spots, appearing 1-4 days prior to the rash, are a characteristic sign of measles. 

Symptoms gradually intensify over a period of 2-4 days until the first day of the rash. The rash typically begins on the forehead (around the hairline), behind the ears, and on the upper neck as a red maculopapular eruption. It then spreads downward to the torso and extremities, often becoming confluent on the face and upper trunk. 

Complications include acute otitis media (most common), pneumonia (the most common cause of death), croup, bronchiolitis, reactivation of tuberculosis, diarrhea, appendicitis, febrile seizures, and encephalitis. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare chronic complication of measles. 

Other options: 

Option B: Leukoplakia appears as a white patch in the oral cavity that cannot be wiped off. 

Option C: Scarlet fever is Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis and is characterized by a distinctive sandpaper rash. The rash appears as a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption that turns the skin bright red and blanches on pressure. It starts around the neck and spreads to the trunk and extremities. 

Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash (maculopapular, erythema multiforme urticarial, or micropustular), conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: What is the secondary attack rate of chickenpox?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate of chicken pox is 85% (range 61–100%)

Chicken pox: 

  • Causative agent: Varicella–zoster virus
  • Incubation period: 2 to 3 weeks
  • Rash: On 1st day, centripetal, pleomorphic, vesiculopapular lesions with erythematous base (dew drops on rose petal)

Treatment: Acyclovir 20 mg/kg/dose; four doses per day; for 5 days

Complications:

  • Cutaneous: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin
  • Systemic: Acute cerebella ataxia, Guillain–Barre syndrome, transverse myelitis, optic neuritis, facial nerve palsy, pneumonia, Reye's syndrome
  • Aspirin is contraindicated due to risk of Reye’s syndrome.

Vaccine:

  • Oka strain (live attenuated)
  • All adults who have never had chickenpox should receive 2 doses 0.5 mL in the deltoid area subcutaneously.
  • For <13 years of age, the first dose is administered at 12–15 months and the second dose at age 4–6 years.
  • For people older than 13 years, the two doses are administered 4–8 weeks apart.
  • For those already immunized, booster doses are not needed if titers are adequate.
